definition[0]: to save something from an accident or bad situation in which other things have already been damaged, destroyed, or lost
example[0]: Divers hope to salvage some of the ship’s cargo.
example[1]: They managed to salvage only a few of their belongings from the fire.
definition[1]: to make sure that you do not lose something completely, or to make sure that something does not fail completely
example[2]: He fought to salvage the company’s reputation.
definition[2]: when you save things from a situation in which other things have already been damaged, destroyed, or lost
definition[3]: things that have been saved from an accident, especially when a ship has sunk
definition[4]: to save goods or property from a situation in which things have already been damaged or destroyed
example[4]: Unsuccessful attempts were made to salvage the ship immediately after it sank.
definition[5]: if someone salvages a deal when there have been serious disagreements and problems about it, they find a way to make people accept it
example[5]: He salvaged a last-minute deal to sell the state’s interests in the bank.
